Authors:
Lorenzo Lombard, Jos Houbraken, Cony Decock, Rob Samson,
Martin Meijer, Martina Reblova, Johannes (Ewald) Zacharias Groenewald,
Pedro W. Crous
Title: Generic hyper-diversity in Stachybotriaceae
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Keywords:
biodegraders, generic concept, human and plant pathogens,
indoor mycobiota multi-gene phylogeny, species concept, taxonomy
Abstract:
The family Stachybotriaceae was recently introduced to
include the genera Myrothecium, Peethambara and Stachybotrys. Members of
this family include important plant and human pathogens, as well as
several species used in industrial and commercial applications as
biodegraders and biocontrol agents. However, the generic boundaries in
Stachybotriaceae are still poorly defined, as type material and sequence
data are not readily available for taxonomic studies. To address this
issue, we performed multi-locus phylogenetic analyses using partial
sequences of the 28S large subunit (LSU), the internal transcribed
spacer region and intervening 5.8S nrRNA gene (ITS), the RNA polymerase
II second largest subunit (rpb2), calmodulin (cmdA), translation
elongation factor 1-alpha (tef1) and Î²-tubulin (tub2) for available type
and authentic strains. Supported by morphological characters these data
resolved 33 genera in the Stachybotriaceae. These included the already
established genera Albosynnema, Alfaria, Didymostilbe, Myrothecium,
Parasarcopodium, Peethambara, Septomyrothecium, Stachybotrys and
Xepicula. At the same time the generic names Dacrydium, Melanopsamma,
Memnoniella and Virgatospora were resurrected. Phylogenetic inference
showed that both the genera Myrothecium and Stachybotrys are
polyphyletic resulting in the introduction of 12 new genera with
myrothecium-like morphology and seven new genera with stachybotrys-like
morphology.
